meanings.definition: Characterized by the belief that the parts of something are intimately interconnected and explicable only by reference to the whole.
meanings.sent1: The wholistic approach to healthcare considers the entire person, not just individual symptoms.
meanings.sent2: She took a wholistic view of the project, considering how each part contributed to the overall success.
meanings.sent3: The wholistic gardener believed that talking to plants could help them grow better.
meanings.sent4: Her wholistic understanding of the ecosystem was like seeing a beautiful tapestry woven together.
meanings.sent5: The wholistic concept of balance in nature resonated deeply with her.

meanings.definition: Relating to or concerned with wholes or with complete systems rather than with the analysis of, treatment of, or dissection into parts.
meanings.sent1: The wholistic approach to education focuses on the overall development of students.
meanings.sent2: He preferred a wholistic approach to problem-solving, looking at the big picture first.
meanings.sent3: The wholistic chef believed that combining all ingredients would create the best dish.
meanings.sent4: Her wholistic view of the company's structure was like seeing a puzzle come together.
meanings.sent5: The wholistic understanding of the universe left him in awe of its complexity.
